questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for routine prenatal screening. She has no significant past medical history and reports feeling well. Her VDRL test comes back positive. Which of the following conditions is NOT a known cause of a false-positive VDRL result?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV drug use

 

Option C:

 

IV drug use itself is not a direct cause of a false-positive VDRL result. False-positive results are commonly associated with conditions that produce antibodies that cross-react with the test antigens, such as autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE), infections (e.g., malaria), or physiological states such as pregnancy.

 

In these conditions, the reagin antibodies are induced against lipid haptens released from the damaged host tissues which may mimic cardiolipin antigens.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. SLE is associated with the production of antiphospholipid antibodies, which can lead to false-positive VDRL results.

 

Option B. Malaria can trigger the production of nonspecific antibodies that may cross-react with antigens used in the VDRL test.

 

Option D. Pregnancy is a physiological state that can occasionally produce nonspecific antibodies leading to a false-positive VDRL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Biological false-positive (BFP) reactions: Nontreponemal tests may give a false-positive result in the absence of syphilis and is also not due to technical faults. The incidence of BFP is generally 1–2%.
  • This is because reagin antibodies may also be found in patients with unrelated diseases such as lepromatous leprosy, relapsing fever, malaria, viral hepatitis, HIV, pregnancy and IV drug abusers

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p377, 2/e p392, Ananthanarayan 9/e p374, 10/e p381

choices.text: Genital ulcer diseases (Chancroid and chancre)
A combination of ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs (Chancroid, chancre, herpes genitalis)

questions.text: In the context of syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in India, which group of symptoms is this approach most applicable for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A combination of ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs (Chancroid, chancre, herpes genitalis)

 

Option C:

 

Immediate syndrome-based treatment is recommended for the usual causes of acute genital ulcerations like syphilis,chancroid and herpes.

 

Syndromic management is designed to address the management of STIs based on the identification of consistent groups of symptoms and easily recognized signs, without laboratory tests. In India, this approach is applicable for a combination of both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs, which includes diseases like chancroid, syphilis (chancre), and herpes genitalis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Only includes two ulcerative STIs, not a combination of different types.

 

Option B. Discharge syndromes refer to different clinical presentations, typically characterized by discharge rather than ulcers.

 

Option D. Includes only ulcerative STIs but does not encompass the full scope of syndromic management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principles of syndromic management in STIs, which involves treatment based on the identification of syndromes associated with STIs, such as ulcers and discharge, rather than specific etiological diagnosis.

 

Ref:   Harrison, 20/e p1285, 19/e p869-75

questions.text: A 5-year-old child in a rural tropical community presents with multiple painless skin ulcers and periostitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pertenue

 

Option A:

 

Treponema pertenue is the causative agent of Yaws, a nonvenereal infection that primarily affects skin and bone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Treponema pallidum is the causative agent of syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection.

 

Option C. Treponema carateum causes Pinta, a skin disease that does not involve bone.

 

Option D. Haemophilus ducreyi causes Chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yaws, a treponemal infection caused by Treponema pertenue, which presents with painless skin ulcers and bone pain in children from tropical areas.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p394

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic with a cough and weight loss. He is suspected of having tuberculosis (TB) and is being prepared for diagnostic evaluation as per the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) guidelines.

 

Question: According to the RNTCP, how many sputum samples should be collected from a patient suspected of having tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Two sample

 

Option B:

 

The RNTCP guidelines suggest collecting 2 sputum samples for the diagnosis of TB: one spot sample at the first visit, a second early morning sample.

 

‘2 sputum smears’ over 2 days period:

 

  • Spot Sample (Day 1)
  • Morning Sample (Day 2)

 

Chances of detecting smear positive cases:

 

  • With 1 Sample : 80%
  • With 2 Sample : 93%

 

Note - Recently CBNAAT test has been added, if Sputum smear results are inconclusive or not available

 

Educational Objective:

 

Number of specimen(s) required for diagnosis of smear positive pulmonary Tuberculosis: TWO 

 

Ref: [Park 27/e p220–222, 489]

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of tuberculosis is diagnosed with extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) after failing to respond to first-line antitubercular therapy. He presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and night sweats. His medical history is significant for TB treatment two years ago. His sputum culture and sensitivity tests confirm resistance to both first-line and second-line drugs. The healthcare team is considering modifying his treatment regimen.

 

Question: Which of the following drugs is commonly included in the treatment regimen for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoroquinolone

 

Option B:

 

Extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) is resistant to isoniazid and rifampin (first-line drugs), any fluoroquinolone, and at least one of three injectable second-line drugs (amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin). Despite this resistance pattern, fluoroquinolones remain a cornerstone in the treatment regimen for XDR-TB due to their effectiveness against mycobacteria and their ability to penetrate into various tissues, including the lungs. Adjusting the regimen to include a fluoroquinolone that the organism is less resistant to can be effective in managing XDR-TB.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amikacin: While used in some multidrug-resistant TB cases, it's often ineffective in XDR-TB due to resistance.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: A first-line anti-TB medication, but XDR-TB is often resistant to it.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: A second-line drug used in some TB cases, but XDR-TB is typically resistant to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The new definition of Pre-XDR-TB is: TB caused by M. tuberculosis strains that fulfil the definition of multidrug resistant and rifampicin-resistant TB (MDR/RR-TB) and which are also resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

 

The updated definition of XDR-TB is: TB caused by M. tuberculosis strains that fulfil the definition of MDR/RR-TB and which are also resistant to any fluoroquinolone and at least one additional Group A drug (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, bedaquiline and linezolid).

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p292

choices.text: It belongs to a new class of antibacterial drugs.
Its mechanism of action involves ATP synthase inhibition.
It is typically prescribed for a 12-month schedule.
It is highly efficient as a solo-drug regimen.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of chronic cough and weight loss has been diagnosed with multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) after failing first-line therapy. She is now being considered for a second-line treatment regimen.

 

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding bedaquiline, a medication used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Its mechanism of action involves ATP synthase inhibition.

 

Option B:

 

Bedaquiline is a new class of antibacterial drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase. It is used for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) when an effective treatment regimen cannot otherwise be composed for reasons of resistance or tolerability. However, the key distinguishing feature of bedaquiline is its unique mechanism of action, which targets ATP synthase, thereby reducing the energy production required for the mycobacterium to survive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While bedaquiline is a new antibacterial class, this is less specific than its mechanism of action.

 

Option C. Bedaquiline is recommended for 24 weeks as part of combination therapy, not typically for a 12-month schedule.

 

Option D. Bedaquiline should not be used as a solo-drug regimen due to the risk of resistance development and is less effective when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline

 

  • Diarylquinoline drug which targets Mycobacterial ATP synthase
  • Extended half-life: Present even 5.5 months after stoppage
  • Significant use in culture-conversion time for MDR-TB
  • Patient selection criteria: Age 18 years or more with MDR-TB
  • Contraindications: Pregnancy, Cardiac arrhythmia

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology2/e p293

questions.text:
In a clinic serving a population with a high prevalence of HIV/AIDS, a 29-year-old patient presents with fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. The patient has a low CD4 count and is being evaluated for opportunistic infections.

 

Question: Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to screen for an opportunistic infection commonly associated with HIV/AIDS using urine samples?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

Option D:

 

The detection of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen in urine is used to screen for tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV/AIDS, due to its ease of collection and rapid results. This test is particularly useful in resource-limited settings and for patients with advanced immunosuppression.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii - Diagnosis is usually made by identifying cysts in respiratory specimens, not urine.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus neoformans - While cryptococcal antigen can be detected in blood or cerebrospinal fluid, it is not typically screened in urine.

 

Option C. Toxoplasma gondii - This parasite is diagnosed through serological tests, not urine tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen in urine is used to screen for tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV/AIDS

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p278

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a high burden TB setting is evaluating diagnostic tests for tuberculosis (TB) to ensure rapid and accurate diagnosis for prompt initiation of treatment.

 

Question: Which of the following laboratory tests for Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires only whole blood as a sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA)

 

Option C:

 

The Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) is a blood test that measures the immune response to the TB bacteria in whole blood. It is used to diagnose latent TB infection and is an alternative to the tuberculin skin test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluorescent staining - This requires respiratory samples, not blood.

 

Option B. GeneXpert MTB - This rapid molecular test also requires respiratory specimens.

 

Option D. ZN staining - The Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used on b, not blood, to identify acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) is the laboratory test for TB that utilizes whole blood as a sample.

 

Ref:  Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p279, 2/e p291

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male with a history of chronic smoking presents with dyspnea and left-sided chest pain. A pleural effusion is suspected, and pleural fluid is sent to the laboratory for analysis to rule out tuberculosis (TB).

 

Question: Which of the following tests cannot be used to measure a parameter from pleural fluid in a suspected case of tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gene Xpert

 

Option A:

 

Gene Xpert (Xpert MTB/RIF) is a molecular test that identifies DNA sequences specific for Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance. It is typically performed on sputum samples, not pleural fluid, to diagnose pulmonary TB and assess for drug resistance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) - Elevated in pleural fluid due to exudative effusions, including TB.

 

Option C. Albumin - Used to differentiate between exudative and transudative pleural effusions.

 

Option D. Adenosine deaminase (ADA) - Elevated levels in pleural fluid are highly suggestive of TB pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gene Xpert is typically used for analyzing sputum sample, not pleural fluid, in suspected cases of TB.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p278, 2/e p288

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK254320/

questions.text:
A 33-year-old male with a history of a positive tuberculin skin test but no active tuberculosis (TB) symptoms is being evaluated for latent TB infection to determine the need for prophylactic treatment.

 

Question: Which agent is used in the interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ESAT-6 (Early Secreted Antigenic Target 6)

 

Option D:

 

The interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs) for latent tuberculosis infection utilize antigens like ESAT-6 and CFP-10 (Culture Filtrate Protein 10) to stimulate T-cells in blood samples. These antigens are specific to Mycobacterium tuberculosis and do not cross-react with the BCG vaccine strain or most non-tuberculous mycobacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MPT 64 - A protein associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex but not used in IGRA.

 

Option B. Mycolic acid - A component of the mycobacterial cell wall, not used in IGRA.

 

Option C. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) - A cell wall component detectable in urine, not used in IGRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ESAT-6 is the specific antigen used in interferon-gamma release assays for diagnosing latent tuberculosis infection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p279, 2/e p291

questions.text: A physician working in a tropical country observes a high prevalence of bacillary dysentery among patients presenting with acute gastroenteritis. Stool cultures often isolate a particular species of Shigella. Which species of Shigella is most commonly isolated in cases of bacillary dysentery in tropical countries like India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shigella flexneri.

 

Option B:

 

Shigella flexneri is the most common cause of bacillary dysentery in developing countries, including those with tropical climates like India. It is responsible for a significant burden of disease in these regions due to factors like overcrowding and poor sanitation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shigella dysenteriae - While this species can cause outbreaks, it is not the most commonly isolated species in tropical countries.

 

Option C. Shigella sonnei - This species is more commonly associated with developed countries.

 

Option D. Shigella boydii - This species is less common and is not typically the predominant cause of bacillary dysentery in tropical countries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p306, 2/e p318, Ananthanarayan 9th/p 288, 10/e p291

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a known history of sickle cell anemia presents to the pediatric clinic with pain in his legs. Radiographic findings are suggestive of osteomyelitis, but there is no evidence of pus formation. Given his underlying condition, which organism is most likely responsible for causing his osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Salmonella species.

 

Option A:

 

Patients with sickle cell anemia are at increased risk for osteomyelitis due to Salmonella species, likely related to microvascular infarctions in the bone leading to a compromised blood supply, which provides an environment conducive to infection with this organism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus - While this is the most common cause of osteomyelitis overall, Salmonella species are more specifically associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae - This organism is not typically associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.

 

Option D. Enterobacter species - These are less common causes of osteomyelitis and are not specifically associated with sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salmonella species are a common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia, particularly when there is no evidence of suppurative infection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2/e,p340

questions.text: A public health officer is planning a vaccination campaign against typhoid fever in a region with high disease prevalence. She wants to ensure that the Vi polysaccharide vaccine is administered at the appropriate age according to standard recommendations. At what age should children receive the Vi typhoid vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 months.

 

Option C:

 

The Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine (Typhim Vi vaccine) is recommended for use in individuals aged two years and older. It is not recommended for children under the age of two because it may not be as effective in this age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vi typhoid vaccine is recommended for children aged two years and older due to the improved immunogenicity at this age.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p236, 2/e p339

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. He mentions that he recently returned from a camping trip in the mountains. On examination, he has a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), and his abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness. A complete blood count shows leukocytosis. Abdominal ultrasonography is suggestive of appendicitis. However, further questioning reveals that he also has diarrhea, which is not typical for appendicitis. Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause an appendicitis-like syndrome along with diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Y. pseudotuberculosis

 

Option B:

 

Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is known to cause a syndrome that can mimic appendicitis, often accompanied by diarrhea. This condition, sometimes referred to as pseudoappendicitis, can lead to right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, much like actual appendicitis. The patient's recent history of camping, where he may have been exposed to contaminated food or water, along with his symptoms, supports this diagnosis. The presence of diarrhea helps differentiate it from typical appendicitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Y. pestis is the causative agent of plague and does not typically present with an appendicitis-like syndrome.

 

Option C. Pasteurella septica is a bacterium commonly associated with animal bites and does not present with appendicitis-like symptoms.

 

Option D. Brucella abortus causes brucellosis and is associated with a variety of nonspecific symptoms including fever and malaise, but not typically an appendicitis-like syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is a causative agent of an appendicitis-like syndrome, particularly in the context of diarrhea and a relevant exposure history.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p315, 2/e p328

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer from a rural community presents to the clinic complaining of a week-long illness characterized by high fever, severe headache, abdominal pain, and fatigue. He also reports painful swelling in his groin area. Physical examination reveals marked inguinal lymphadenopathy, and the patient also starts to vomit during the exam. He has a history of handling livestock and recently assisting with the birth of lambs. A blood sample is taken and sent for laboratory analysis. Given the patient's symptoms and occupational exposure, which stain would most likely aid in the diagnosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wayson's stain

 

Option B:

 

Wayson's stain is typically used in the identification of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, which is characterized by symptoms such as fever, headache, chills, and swollen, painful lymph nodes called buboes, as seen in bubonic plague. The patient's occupation and the symptom of painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are classic for bubonic plague, which can be contracted through contact with infected animals or fleas. Wayson's stain would reveal the bipolar "safety pin" appearance of the bacteria.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neisser stain is used for the detection of Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Neisseria meningitidis and is not appropriate for plague.

 

Option C. Albert's stain is used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Option D. McFadyean's stain is used for the detection of Bacillus anthracis spores, which do not match the patient's symptoms and exposure history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wayson's stain is a crucial diagnostic tool for identifying Yersinia pestis, the bacterium responsible for the plague. This staining method is effective in revealing the characteristic bipolar "safety pin" appearance of the bacteria. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p313, 2/e p326, Ananthanarayan 9/e p323, 10/e p326

choices.text: Escherichia coli

questions.text: A laboratory technician is processing various bacterial cultures from a series of clinical samples. One particular sample from a catheter site infection demonstrates a striking red pigment on the culture media after incubation. The attending microbiologist decides to use this opportunity to quiz the technician on the possible identity of the bacterium. Which of the following bacteria is known for producing a red pigment and is likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratia marcescens

 

Option D:

 

Serratia marcescens is a gram-negative bacterium known for producing a characteristic red pigment, especially when cultured at room temperature. This pigment is called prodigiosin and can be a useful clue in identifying this organism in the laboratory.

 

 

Figure: Serratia on Nutrient Agar

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli does not typically produce a red pigment.

 

Option B. Bordetella parapertussis is known for causing whooping cough and does not produce a red pigment.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa can produce various pigments, typically green-blue, not red.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serratia marcescens by its characteristic production of a red pigment, prodigiosin, on culture media.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p309, 2/e p322, Ananthnarayan 9/e p281, 10/e 288

choices.text: Inactivation of elongation factor-2
Inhibition of neurotransmitter release
Activation of adenylate cyclase
Disruption of protein synthesis by cleaving 60S ribosomal subunit

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with acute onset of profuse watery diarrhea and vomiting. She reports attending a local food festival 2 days prior. Examination reveals dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Stool analysis is pending, but you suspect a toxigenic bacterial infection based on the clinical presentation. In managing this patient, understanding the mechanisms of bacterial toxins is crucial. Which of the following mechanisms of action is associated with the toxin produced by the organism most likely causing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Activation of adenylate cyclase.

 

Option C:

 

Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, the likely causative agent given the clinical scenario, acts by the ADP-ribosylation of the Gs alpha subunit of the G protein-coupled receptor. This action leads to the continuous activation of adenylate cyclase, which then increases cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels within intestinal epithelial cells, causing a massive outflow of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic "rice water" stools seen in cholera.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inactivation of elongation factor-2 is the mechanism by which diphtheria toxin acts, not cholera toxin.

 

Option B. Inhibition of neurotransmitter release is the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Disruption of protein synthesis by cleaving 60S ribosomal subunit is the mechanism of action of Shiga toxin and not cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mechanism of action of cholera toxin as the activation of adenylate cyclase leading to increased cAMP in intestinal epithelial cells and resultant secretory diarrhea.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p343

choices.text: It is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.
The disease is a gram-negative aerobic infection.
The most common form of the disease is a pulmonary infection.
The causative organism is typically non motile.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old male from a Southeast Asian country presents with a high fever, weight loss, and a productive cough for the past month. He has a history of soil-related occupational exposure and has an ulceration on his leg that has not healed over several months. A sputum sample reveals Gram-negative bacilli with bipolar "safety pin" appearance.

 

 

Which of the following statements about his condition is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The causative organism is typically non motile

 

Option D:

 

The patient's presentation is suggestive of melioidosis, which is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, a Gram-negative, aerobic, motile bacillus found in soil and water. Melioidosis can present in various forms, the most common being pulmonary infection, but it can also cause skin infections, abscesses, and even septicemia.

 

Additional Points to remember – 

 

  • Incubation period: 2 days to many years. 
  • Has long latency; presented long time after the exposure; hence also known as ‘Vietnam time-bomb disease’.
  • Clinical feature: Can present with an array of manifestations, hence called as ‘great mimicker’ from acute, localized infection to sub-acute tuberculosis like Pulmonary infection to Chronic suppurative infection forming abscesses in various organs
  • Ashdown’s medium is used as a selective medium, where it produces wrinkled purple colonies. Cultures can be confirmed by latex agglutination test using specific antisera.
     

 

Figure: Burkholderia pseudomallei: A: gram stain showing gram negative bacilli with safety pin or bipolar staining , B: Rough and corrugated colonies on Mac Conkey Agar , C: Wrinkled purplecolonies on Ashdown Medium

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Burkholderia pseudomallei does indeed cause melioidosis, which aligns with the patient’s occupation and symptoms.

 

Option B. The agent is a gram-negative aerobic bacterium, which is consistent with the sputum sample findings.

 

Option C. The most common form of melioidosis is pulmonary infection, presenting with symptoms like cough, high fever, and weight loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei, a motile, gram-negative aerobic bacterium, causes melioidosis, often presenting as pulmonary infection. While the organism is known for its motility, contrary to option d, it typically manifests in pulmonary forms, aligning with the patient's symptoms of cough and fever. 

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p342-43, 2/e p356, Ananthanarayan 9/e p317, 10/e p323’

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with no significant medical history presents to the pediatric emergency department with fever, drooling, and difficulty breathing. He appears anxious, has a muffled voice, and prefers sitting upright. On examination, he has a swollen and erythematous epiglottis. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemophilus influenzae type b

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of acute epiglottitis, a medical emergency characterized by inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis. Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) is the most common causative organism of epiglottitis in unvaccinated children. The child's symptoms of fever, drooling, difficulty breathing, and pRef:   for an upright position are classic signs of epiglottitis due to Hib.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia and otitis media, not typically associated with acute epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus could cause epiglottitis, but it is less common than Hib.

 

Option D. Moraxella catarrhalis commonly causes otitis media and sinusitis, not acute epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) is identified as the primary cause of acute epiglottitis, particularly in unvaccinated children. Other bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Moraxella catarrhalis are associated with different respiratory infections. For instance, Streptococcus pneumoniae commonly leads to pneumonia and otitis media, while Staphylococcus aureus can cause epiglottitis but is less prevalent than Hib. 

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p348, 2/e p362

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with severe abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. Upon examination, the patient is found to have necrotic lesions in the intestine. Which organism is most commonly associated with this presentation, known as gastrointestinal enteritis necroticans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clostridium perfringens. 

 

Option B:

 

Clostridium perfringens, particularly type C strains, is known to cause gastrointestinal enteritis necroticans, also known as Pig-bel disease, which is characterized by necrotic lesions in the intestine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Clostridium difficile is associated with antibiotic-associated diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis, not enteritis necroticans.

 

Option C: Clostridium botulinum is associated with botulism, a form of food poisoning that affects the nervous system.

 

Option D: Campylobacter jejuni is a common cause of bacterial gastroenteritis but does not typically cause enteritis necroticans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium perfringens as the causative agent of gastrointestinal enteritis necroticans, a serious intestinal disease.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p258, 2/e p268, Ananthanarayan 9/e p255, 56, 10/e p260

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes. His physician suspects infectious mononucleosis and orders a Paul Bunnel test. What is the principle of the Paul Bunnel test used in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Heterophile agglutination test

 

Option A:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is a type of heterophile agglutination test, typically used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. In this test, sheep red blood cells (RBCs) are used to detect cross-reacting antibodies present in the patient's serum. These heterophile antibodies are not specific to the Epstein-Barr virus but react with antigens present in sheep red blood cells, leading to agglutination.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Neutralization test - This is used to measure the ability of antibodies to neutralize the biological activity of an antigen, not typically used for infectious mononucleosis.
 

Option C. Complement mediated cell damage - This involves the use of the complement system to assess cell lysis or damage, not the principle behind the Paul Bunnel test.
 

Option D. Agglutination reaction - While this is a type of agglutination test, it is more specifically a heterophile agglutination test, making the option more accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is an example of Heterophile agglutination test; done for infectious mononucleosis (caused by Epstein- Barr virus). Here, sheep red blood cell (RBC) antigens are used to detect cross-reacting antibodies in patient’s sera

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p106, 2/e p132, Ananthanarayan 10/e p111

questions.text: In an emergency department, a physician treats a patient with a severe bacterial infection. The physician notes that certain components of the patient's immune system are facilitating phagocytosis by marking the bacteria for easier identification and engulfment by phagocytes. Which of the following is acting as an opsonin in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C3b

 

Option B:

 

Opsonins (like Fc of IgG and complement factors like C3b, C4b and ic3b) play a very important role in uptake of bacteria by binding to the specific molecules on the surface of bacteria thus facilitating the engulfment by the phagocyte (which bear the receptors for the opsonins).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C3a: This is an anaphylatoxin involved in inflammation, not an opsonin.

 

Option C. C5a: Also an anaphylatoxin, C5a enhances inflammation and recruits immune cells, but does not function as an opsonin.

 

Option D. LTB4: Leukotriene B4 is involved in inflammation and leukocyte recruitment, not as an opsonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3b, a fragment of the complement protein C3, serves as an opsonin, playing a key role in the immune system by binding to bacteria surfaces and marking them for phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p170, 2/e p148, Ananthanarayan 9/e p112, 10/e p114

choices.text: Antigen and antibody are equal
Antigen and antibody are low

questions.text: A 28-year-old laboratory technician is conducting a study on immune responses using a precipitation assay. In this assay, she is observing the formation of immune complexes in different ratios of antigen to antibody. To achieve the most efficient and visible antigen-antibody reaction in her experiment, what ratio of antigen to antibody should she aim for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antigen and antibody are equal

 

Option C:

 

Marrack's Lattice Hypothesis, formulated in 1934, provides a foundational understanding of antigen-antibody (Ag-Ab) reactions in immunology, particularly in the context of serological testing. This hypothesis explains the varying outcomes of these reactions based on the relative concentrations of antigens and antibodies in a mixture. Here are the key aspects:

 

  • Zone of Equivalence: In the middle test tubes of a serial dilution, where antigen and antibody concentrations are equivalent, the Ag-Ab reaction is most effective. 
  • Prozone Phenomenon: In the initial test tubes, where there's an excess of antibodies, the Ag-Ab reaction is inhibited, leading to the prozone phenomenon. Despite the presence of antibodies, the excess prevents the formation of a well-structured lattice, resulting in a weaker or non-visible reaction.
  • Postzone Phenomenon: overabundance of antigen disrupts the formation of a structured lattice.
  • Clinical Implications: The prozone phenomenon has significant clinical relevance. In serology, samples with a high antibody titer may sometimes yield false-negative results if not properly diluted. Therefore, conducting serial dilutions of sera is crucial to avoid misinterpretation of results.


Explanation:

 

Option A. Excess antibody: This can lead to the prozone effect, where excess antibodies interfere with the formation of visible immune complexes.

 

Option B. Excess antigen: This results in the postzone phenomenon, where there are insufficient antibodies to form visible complexes.

 

Option D. Antigen and antibody are low: Insufficient concentrations of either may not provide enough reactants for detectable immune complex formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Marrack's Lattice Hypothesis, elucidates antigen-antibody (Ag-Ab) reactions in serological testing, highlighting the importance of their relative concentrations. The optimal Ag-Ab reaction, known as the "zone of equivalence," occurs when antigens and antibodies are in equal concentration, facilitating the formation of large, alternating lattices of antigen and antibody molecules. 

 

Conversely, imbalances like excess antibodies (leading to the prozone effect) or excess antigens (resulting in the postzone phenomenon) disrupt lattice formation, causing weaker or non-visible reactions. 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p122, 2/e p128, Ananthanarayan 9/e p105, 10/e p107

questions.text: During a lecture on the lymphatic system, a professor asks the class to identify which of the following is not a peripheral lymphoid organ. Which is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymus

 

Option D:

 

Figure: Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. LN: Lymph nodes are peripheral lymphoid organs.

 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is a peripheral lymphoid organ.

 

Option C. MALT: Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue is a peripheral lymphoid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p146-7, 2/e p152, Kuby’s Immunology 6/e p45-46

choices.text: Mature thymocytes express CD 4 and CD 8
Thymocytes whose T-cell receptor binds with high affinity to self-antigens and MHC complexes are clonally deleted
Mature thymocytes express surface IgM and IgD
CD 4 and CD 8 double positive cells are completely eliminated by a process of negative selection

questions.text: A 26-year-old medical student is studying the process of T-cell maturation. During a lecture on thymic selection, the professor emphasizes a key feature of mature thymocytes. The student learns that a crucial step in preventing autoimmunity involves the fate of thymocytes that interact with self-antigens. Which of the following statements is true regarding mature thymocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymocytes whose T-cell receptor binds with high affinity to self-antigens and MHC complexes are clonally deleted.

 

Option B:


Mature thymocytes that bind with high affinity to self-antigens and MHC complexes undergo clonal deletion. This process, known as negative selection, is essential to prevent autoimmune reactions by eliminating potentially self-reactive T cells during their development in the thymus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mature thymocytes express CD 4 and CD 8: These markers are expressed by immature thymocytes, not mature ones.

 

Option C. Mature thymocytes express surface IgM and IgD: These are markers for B cells, not thymocytes.

 

Option D. CD 4 and CD 8 double positive cells are completely eliminated by a process of negative selection: While negative selection affects these cells, not all double positive cells are eliminated.

 

Educational Objective: 


In the thymus, mature thymocytes that exhibit high-affinity binding to self-antigens and MHC (Major Histocompatibility Complex) complexes undergo clonal deletion. This process, known as negative selection, is crucial for preventing autoimmune diseases by eliminating T cells that are potentially self-reactive during their development in the thymus. This ensures that the mature T cells released into the peripheral immune system are tolerant to the body's own tissues.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p162, 2/e p157, Ananthanarayan 9/e p152, 10/e p154.

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the functions of CD4+ helper T cells in an immunology class. The professor presents various functions of these cells and asks which one is not attributed to CD4+ helper cells. Which of the following is NOT a function of CD4+ helper T cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Produce immunoglobulins

 

Option B:


CD4+ helper T cells do not produce immunoglobulins. This function is specific to B cells. CD4+ helper T cells play a crucial role in assisting other cells of the immune system, such as B cells (to produce antibodies) and macrophages, and in activating cytotoxic T cells, but they do not produce antibodies themselves.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immunogenic memory: CD4+ T cells are involved in forming immunological memory.

 

Option C. Activate macrophages: They help in the activation of macrophages.

 

Option D. Activate cytotoxic cells: CD4+ T cells assist in the activation of cytotoxic T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary roles of CD4+ helper T cells – 

 

  1. Aiding B cells in antibody production: critical role in stimulating B cells to produce immunoglobulins.
  2. Forming Immunological Memory, ensuring a faster and more effective response to pathogens the body has previously encountered.
  3. Activating Macrophages: They assist in activating macrophages, which are vital for engulfing and destroying pathogens.
  4. Assisting the Activation of Cytotoxic T Cells, which are responsible for directly killing infected or cancerous cells.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p166, 2/e p172

questions.text: A research team is studying the role of macrophages in the immune response. They are particularly interested in the cytokines produced by macrophages and their effects. Which cytokine is predominantly produced by macrophages?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  IL-1

 

Option A:


Macrophages are a major source of interleukin-1 (IL-1). IL-1 is a key cytokine involved in the inflammatory response, promoting fever and the activation of lymphocytes. It plays a significant role in both innate and adaptive immunity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. IL-5: Mainly produced by T cells, involved in eosinophil activation.

 

Option C. IL-7: Important for lymphocyte development, not predominantly produced by macrophages.

 

Option D. IFN-γ: Mainly produced by T cells and NK cells, not primarily by macrophages.

 

Educational Objectives: 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p153-4, 2/e p159-160, Kuby’s Immunology 6/e p209 Macrophage produces various secretory molecules

choices.text: Antigen is presented via MHC–I complexes
APCs are required before a response to viruses are generated
Direct antibody stimulation still requires APC’s
Antigen processed by APC are recognized by CD 4+ T Cells

questions.text: Researchers are developing a new agent to enhance the recognition of foreign antigens by antigen-presenting cells (APCs). As part of their research, they are reviewing the physiological aspects of APCs. Which of the following statements is true regarding the functions of APCs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antigen processed by APC are recognized by CD 4+ T Cells

 

Option D:

 

Antigen-presenting cells process antigens and present them on their surface via MHC II molecules to CD4+ T cells. Exogenous (foreign) antigens are first phagocytosed by APCs, then they are processed by APCs and presented on the surface of APCs along with MHC II to be recognized by CD 4+ T Cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antigen is presented via MHC–I complexes: This is more characteristic of cells presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells.

 

Option B. APCs are required before a response to viruses are generated: While true, APCs are not exclusively required for viral responses.

 

Option C. Direct antibody stimulation still requires APC’s: B cells can be directly stimulated by antigens without APCs in some cases.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Antigens processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) are indeed recognized by CD4+ T cells. This recognition is a key step in the immune response:

 

Role of APCs: APCs, like dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells, process exogenous (foreign) antigens and present them on their surface bound to MHC II molecules.

 

Interaction with CD4+ T Cells: These MHC II-antigen complexes on APCs are recognized by CD4+ T cells. The interaction is crucial for the activation and differentiation of CD4+ T cells, leading to various immune responses, including helper functions for other immune cells.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p162, 2/e p170

choices.text: O Rh D +
O Rh D –

questions.text: In emergency situations where there is no time for blood cross-matching, Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) transfusion decisions are based on the universal donor concept. However, unlike red blood cells, the universal donor for plasma is based on the AB blood group, not the O blood group. This is because plasma contains antibodies, and the AB blood group is considered the universal plasma donor since it doesn't contain anti-A or anti-B antibodies. Therefore, the safest option for transfusing FFP in a trauma patient without cross-matching would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AB Rh D –

 

Option D:


AB Rh D – (AB negative) plasma is considered the safest option for emergency transfusion when there is no time for cross-matching, as it contains neither A nor B antibodies and also lacks the Rh factor, making it suitable for all patients regardless of their blood type.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. O Rh D +: O group plasma contains both anti-A and anti-B antibodies, which can cause reactions in recipients with A, B, or AB blood types.

 

Option B. O Rh D –: Although Rh negative is preferable, O group plasma is still not ideal due to the presence of anti-A and anti-B antibodies.

 

Option C. AB Rh D +: While AB plasma is suitable due to lack of anti-A and anti-B antibodies, Rh positive plasma could cause problems for Rh negative recipients.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Universal donor: Individuals with ‘O’ Rh D negative blood group are called as universal donors because they do not possess either A or B antigen or Rh antigen; hence, they are generally safe. The anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the transfused O blood group are diluted in recipient’s serum, do not ordinarily cause any damage to the red cells of the A or B blood group recipients.

 

Universal recipients: Individuals with AB Rh D positive blood group do not have both A and B antibodies or Rh D antibodies in serum; therefore, they can receive any other blood group. Hence, they are called universal recipients.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p214

choices.text: Antibody to anti- Ca receptor
Blockage of nerve conduction through myoneural junction

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, which worsens with activity and improves with rest. Based on her symptoms, which of the following is true about Myasthenia Gravis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Antibody to Ach (Acetylcholine) receptor

 

Option A:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by the presence of antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired neuromuscular transmission and muscle weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Antibody to anti- Ca receptor: Not associated with Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Option C. Ach is not secreted: Acetylcholine is secreted but its action is impaired due to antibody binding.

 

Option D. Blockage of nerve conduction: The primary issue is at the neuromuscular junction, not nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathophysiology of Myasthenia Gravis - involves antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptor, leading to impaired neuromuscular transmission.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology, 2/e p191

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with high-grade fever and chills. He has a travel history. His pulse rate is noted to be relatively slower than what would be expected for his fever. In which of the following conditions is relative bradycardia uncommon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Factitious fever

 

Option D: 

Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign (a lower-than-expected heart rate given the high body temperature), is uncommon In Factitious fever. 
 

In factitious fever (fever artificially induced or faked), the pulse is usually normal or exaggerated for the supposed fever, and many physiological signs don't match the claimed symptoms.
 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Brucellosis: Can present with relative bradycardia.

 

Option B. Typhoid: Known to show relative bradycardia.

 

Option C. Yes, can sometimes present with relative bradycardia, especially Plasmodium falciparum during febrile spikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative bradycardia is seen in typhoid fever, Legionnaires disease, Scrub typhus and Chlamydia, Babesia, Brucellosis, Rickettsial infections, Ebola/Marburg virus, dengue, yellow fever and non-infectious cases such as CNS lesions (central fever), lymphoma and Drug Fever

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p660

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female presents with redness, pain, and decreased vision in her right eye. She has a history of contact lens wear and reports sleeping in them occasionally. On examination, there is a white infiltrate in the cornea and a small hypopyon. The fluorescein staining result is shown in the below image. No discharge is noted.

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her corneal infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

Option B: 

The presence of a dendritic ulcer on fluorescein staining is highly suggestive of herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Herpes keratoconjunctivitis is primarily caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1, transmitted through kissing or close personal contact. HSV-2, known for genital infections, can also affect the eyes in adults through oculogenital contact. The disease presents in two main forms:

 

  1. Conjunctivitis: This presents as follicular conjunctivitis, often accompanying herpes lesions on the face and eyelids, and is typically associated with preauricular lymphadenopathy.
  2. Keratitis: This involves corneal damage and can manifest in various forms:
  • Epithelial keratitis: Characterized by patterns like epithelial punctate keratitis, dendritic ulcers (irregular, zigzag linear branching shaped), and geographical ulcers.
  • Stromal keratitis: This is the involvement of the corneal stroma.
  • Additionally, herpes keratoconjunctivitis can lead to uveitis, presenting as non-granulomatous iridocyclitis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus - Commonly causes blepharitis and can cause keratitis, but not typically associated with dendritic ulcers.

 

 

Figure: A. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis; B. Angular conjunctivitis

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa - A serious cause of keratitis in contact lens wearers but more commonly presents with rapid, aggressive infection and corneal ulceration without dendritic ulcers.

 

 

Figure: Corneal ulcer: A. Oval-shaped; B. Ring.

 

For option A & C- Bacterial keratitis, primarily caused by S. aureus, Pseudomonas, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Infection reaches the cornea endogenously from adjacent structures or exogenously from water or air, leading to purulent corneal ulcers characterized by eye pain, blurred vision, and yellowish-white lesions. Pseudomonas infections are particularly aggressive, potentially causing rapid corneal damage. 

 

Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scraping for culture and microscopy

 

Treatment - Topical antibiotics, such as Cefazolin and Tobramycin, with frequent instillation, and in severe cases, systemic antibiotics like cephalosporin. 

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba - Acanthamoeba keratitis is an ocular infection often linked to contact lens use. These amoebae can adhere to the corneal epithelium, especially in cases of corneal injury or post-surgery, leading to severe ocular problems like corneal ulcers, iritis, and vision loss. 

 

Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scrapings examined under wet mount, revealing trophozoites and cysts, and further confirmed by PCR. 

 

Treatment - Topical antiseptics such as 0.1% propamidine and in severe cases, penetrating keratoplasty. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of keratitis, specifically herpetic keratitis. The presence of a dendritic ulcer on fluorescein staining is highly suggestive of herpes simplex virus infection. This virus is a common cause of corneal infection, especially in the context of contact lens wear.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 4/e Chapter 78, page 779.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of fever, dyspnea, and a non-productive cough. He recently attended a crowded international conference. Chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum and bilateral infiltrates. The patient rapidly progresses to severe respiratory distress. A history of similar cases among other conference attendees is reported.

 

Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis (Anthrax)

 

Option A:

 

The clinical presentation of sudden onset fever, respiratory distress, widened mediastinum, and bilateral infiltrates in a patient who attended a crowded event is highly suggestive of inhalational anthrax. Bacillus anthracis, a Category A bioterrorism agent, can cause severe respiratory disease when inhaled and is known for its potential use as a bioweapon due to its high mortality rate and potential for rapid dissemination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Variola major (Smallpox) - Typically presents with fever and a characteristic rash, not primarily with respiratory symptoms.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis (Plague) - While it can cause pneumonic plague, it is less likely in this scenario given the rapid progression and specific radiological findings.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis (Tularemia) - Can cause pneumonic tularemia but is less likely than anthrax to present with a widened mediastinum and rapid progression in a bioterrorism scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diseases caused by Bacillus anthrax -

 

  1. Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porter's disease)  (Malignant pustule)
  2. Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter's disease) (Inhalation anthrax)
  3. Gastrointestinal anthrax

 

Bioterrorism agent – 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 4/e Chapter 81, page 807.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a genital ulcer. He reports the ulcer appeared about two weeks ago and describes it as moderately painful. On examination, the ulcer is soft and there is marked inguinal lymphadenopathy with tender, swollen lymph nodes. Which of the following STIs is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Option C: 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by a painful, soft genital ulcer and painful, marked inguinal lymphadenopathy, often leading to bubo formation. The incubation period of 1–14 days aligns with the patient's history. The presentation of a painful ulcer and significant lymphadenopathy is typical for chancroid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Typically presents with a painless, indurated, single ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy. This does not match the patient's symptoms of a painful ulcer and painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Herpes: Herpes genitalis usually presents with multiple, painful ulcers. However, the marked lymphadenopathy described in this patient is more consistent with chancroid.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, LGV can present with genital ulcers but is more characterized by painful and soft lymphadenopathy, which can be similar to chancroid. However, the nature of the ulcer in LGV (single or multiple) and the longer incubation period make chancroid more likely in this case.

 

Differential diagnoses 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p 343, 2/e p671

choices.text: Caused by shiga-like toxin-producing E.coli

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and mild fever. He reports recent travel to a developing country where he recalls consuming local street food. On examination, he appears dehydrated. His stool culture report indicates the presence of Shigella species.

 

Which of the following is an indication for the use of antibiotics in this patient with acute diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: In this case, the patient has symptoms suggestive of traveler's diarrhea, which is often caused by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) and is an indication for antibiotic therapy to shorten the duration of diarrhea. Bacillary dysentery, caused by Shigella, is also an indication for antibiotics to reduce the severity and transmission of infection. Diarrhea caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) is another indication, as antibiotics can help reduce the duration and severity of illness. Cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae, also warrants antibiotic treatment to decrease fluid requirements and disease duration. Therefore, all the options listed are indications for antibiotic use in acute diarrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Traveller’s diarrhea: Antibiotics are indicated for moderate to severe cases, especially those involving fever, bloody stools, or significant dehydration.

 

Option B. Bacillary dysentery: Caused by Shigella, antibiotics reduce the duration of symptoms and infectiousness.

 

Option C. Caused by Shiga-like toxin-producing E.coli: Antibiotics are used to reduce the severity and duration of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common causes of Traveller’s Diarrhea

 

 

  • Most common cause - Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli   > Enteroaggregative E. coli
  • Campylobacter jejuni - more common in Asia.
  • Norovirus diarrhea - associated with traveling on cruise ships.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p649

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from Delhi with a history of untreated HIV presents to the clinic with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. On examination, he is found to have photophobia and a positive Brudzinski's sign. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows an elevated protein level with a low glucose concentration. India has a high prevalence of tuberculosis; however, fungal infections are also considered in differential diagnosis due to his immunocompromised state. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the causative agent in this patient's CSF?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) India ink preparation

 

Option B:

 

India ink preparation is used to visualize Cryptococcus neoformans, a fungus that can cause meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS. The test takes advantage of the organism's thick polysaccharide capsule, which does not take up the ink, resulting in a clear halo around the yeast cells.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ziehl-Neelsen stain: This is typically used to identify acid-fast bacilli, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and would not be appropriate for detecting Cryptococcus in CSF.

 

Option C. Gram stain: While Gram stain can identify a variety of bacteria, it is not the best choice for fungi as the thick capsule of Cryptococcus may resist staining.

 

Option D. KOH preparation: Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used for detecting fungal elements in skin, nails, and hair but is not the optimal choice for visualizing Cryptococcus in CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic tests for identifying infectious agents in the CSF of an immunocompromised patient. India ink preparation is a specific test for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a common cause of meningitis in HIV/AIDS patients. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p569, 2/e p593, Ananthanarayan 9/e p613

questions.text: In a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis, a condition that predisposes to certain fungal infections due to altered phagocytic function, which organism is most likely to cause orbital cellulitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mucor

 

Option C:

 

In the context of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), patients are particularly susceptible to mucormycosis, caused by fungi from the Mucorales order, including Mucor. DKA creates an environment with high serum glucose levels and acidic conditions, which impairs neutrophil function. This immune dysfunction makes patients more vulnerable to opportunistic fungal infections like mucormycosis. Mucormycosis can manifest as a serious infection like orbital cellulitis, a condition where the infection spreads to the eye socket. This is a medical emergency and requires prompt treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus is more commonly associated with central nervous system infections, particularly meningitis in immunocompromised patients, and would not present with the described histopathological findings.

 

Option B. Candida species are not typically associated with invasive sinus and orbital infections in diabetic patients.

 

Option D. Aspergillus species typically cause a more chronic form of sinusitis and orbital involvement and are characterized by septate hyphae that branch at acute angles.

 

Educational Objective:

In diabetic ketoacidosis, the high serum glucose levels and acidic environment impair neutrophil function, making patients particularly susceptible to mucormycosis.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570, 2/e p594

choices.text: The nose is a common site of infection.
Diabetes is a common predisposing factor.
The condition is common in India.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman from Bengaluru presents with sinus pain, fever, and a black necrotic eschar on her nasal mucosa. She has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. Based on the increased incidence in India, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above.

 

Option D:

 

This patient is likely suffering from mucormycosis, a fungal infection caused by Mucorales fungi, which is known to affect the nasal and sinus regions, particularly in diabetic patients, and has a noted prevalence in India.

 

  • Rhinocerebral zygomycosis is the most common and fulminant type of zygomycosis, affecting nose, paranasal sinuses, orbit and palate.
  • Risk factor- MC is Diabetes followed by patient on dialysis, iron overload and Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
  • Mucormycosis is increasingly recognized in recently developed countries, such as India, mainly in patients with uncontrolled diabetes or trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's diabetes and geographic location (India), along with her symptoms (sinus pain and black necrotic eschar), point towards a diagnosis of mucormycosis, which is more prevalent in India and commonly affects the nasal area in diabetic patients.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570-71, 2/e p594

choices.text: ARDS with widespread hyaline membrane formation
Interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates

questions.text: A 40-year-old individual with HIV/AIDS from Mumbai presents with shortness of breath and a non-productive cough. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Considering the patient's immunocompromised status, which morphological appearance of a fungal infection is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates

 

Option C:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in patients with HIV/AIDS and presents with interstitial pneumonitis characterized by foamy intra-alveolar exudates on histopathological examination.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic and necrotizing pneumonia: This type of pneumonia is often caused by bacterial infections, particularly by aggressive pathogens like certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is characterized by the destruction of lung tissue and bleeding into the alveoli and is not typically seen with Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.

 

Option B. ARDS with widespread hyaline membrane formation: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a severe, diffuse inflammatory response in the lungs that leads to acute onset of respiratory failure. It can be caused by various factors, including severe infections, trauma, or inhalation injuries. The hyaline membranes are a hallmark of ARDS, representing protein-rich edema fluid and cellular debris within alveoli. Although patients with Pneumocystis pneumonia can develop ARDS, this is a complication rather than a direct morphological characteristic of the organism itself.

 

Option D. Bronchopulmonary abscess formation: Abscesses in the lung are localized collections of pus within lung tissue, often caused by bacterial infections, particularly in the setting of aspiration pneumonia. They are characterized by a necrotic center surrounded by inflammatory cells and are not typical of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which does not commonly cause localized suppuration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristics of Pneumocystis jirovecii infection - the presence of interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates, especially those who are immunocompromised.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600, Harrison 19/e p1359

questions.text: In the context of a microbial taxonomy lecture in New Delhi, a professor asks the students to identify the organism classified as a fungus. Which of the following is correctly classified as such?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Option C:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is correctly classified as a fungus. It was historically considered to be a protozoan due to its morphology and clinical presentation, but later genetic studies revealed that it is more closely related to fungi. Pneumocystis jirovecii is known for causing Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: This is a genus of bacteria, known for causing a range of infections including pneumonia and urinary tract infections. It is not a fungus.

 

Option B. Clostridia: This is a genus of bacteria, which includes species such as Clostridium difficile, known for causing severe colitis, and Clostridium botulinum, known for causing botulism. It is also not a fungus.

 

Option D. Listeria: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterium that can cause listeriosis, a serious infection usually caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium. Again, it is not a fungus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus that can cause pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised hosts.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600, Harrison 18/e

1673

choices.text: Detection of the poliovirus in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Detection of poliovirus antibodies in serum
Isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens

questions.text: A health worker in a polio surveillance program is evaluating a case of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) in a child. To confirm the diagnosis of polio, which of the following is the most reliable and standard method of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C). Isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens

 

Option C:

 

The gold standard for the diagnosis of poliomyelitis is the isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens. This method is preferred due to the virus's fecal-oral route of transmission and the prolonged shedding of the virus in the stool of infected individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The poliovirus is rarely detected in the CSF, which makes it an unreliable method for confirming polio.

 

Option B. Serological tests can indicate a past infection or immunization but are not definitive for acute infection.

 

Option D. EMG can show findings suggestive of polio but is not diagnostic; the virus must be isolated for confirmation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens is the standard diagnostic method for poliomyelitis, particularly in the context of acute flaccid paralysis surveillance.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p477, 2/e p496, Park 23/e p203-9, 24/e p218

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presents with fever, oral lesions, and a rash on the hands and feet. The oral lesions are painful, with a red base and a small blister on top. The rash on the hands and feet consists of small, red, flat lesions. 

 

 

Which virus is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackie A virus

 

Option A:

 

Coxsackie A virus is the most likely cause of the child's symptoms, which are characteristic of hand, foot, and mouth disease. This illness typically presents with a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa, and Coxsackie A virus (particularly serotypes A16 and A6) is a common etiological agent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pox virus causes molluscum contagiosum and smallpox, which present differently.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex type 1 virus causes oral herpes, which typically does not present with a rash on the hands and feet.

 

Option D. Togavirus, which includes Rubella virus, does not cause these specific symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie A virus is the common cause of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in young children, characterized by fever, oral lesions, and a rash on the hands and feet.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1e/p480

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a high-grade fever, headache, and altered mental status. The mother also reports that the child has been experiencing vomiting and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed, showing an increase in white blood cells with a lymphocytic predominance. Which of the following viruses is the most common cause of viral meningoencephalitis in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteroviruses

 

Option B:

 

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and meningoencephalitis in children, particularly during summer and fall. The clinical presentation and cerebrospinal fluid profile are suggestive of viral meningoencephalitis, which is most frequently caused by enteroviruses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arboviruses can cause meningoencephalitis but are less common than enteroviruses.

 

Option C. Herpes viruses, particularly HSV-1, can cause encephalitis, often with a more severe presentation and focal findings on imaging.

 

Option D. Mumps viruses can cause meningoencephalitis but have become less common due to vaccination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteroviruses is the most common etiologic agent for viral meningoencephalitis in children

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480-81, 2/e p500-501

questions.text: An outbreak of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis has been reported in a local school. Public health officials are trying to identify the causative agent. Which enterovirus serotype is most commonly associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serotype 70

 

Option C:

 

Enterovirus serotype 70 is one of the main causes of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which is a highly contagious eye infection that can cause eye pain, redness, swelling, and subconjunctival hemorrhage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serotype 68 is not typically associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Serotype 69 has not been commonly linked to acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Serotype 71 is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease and herpangina, not typically with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus serotype 70 as a causative agent of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis during outbreaks of the disease

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480-81, 2/e p500-501

choices.text: All of the above are correct associations

questions.text: A public health worker is investigating an outbreak of viral illnesses in a small community. The symptoms range from herpangina in children to acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis in adults. The worker needs to identify the viruses responsible for these illnesses to guide the community health response. Which of the following associations between viruses and diseases is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above are correct associations

 

Explanation:

 

Coxsackie A virus is commonly associated with herpangina, characterized by fever, sore throat, and small vesicular lesions in the oropharynx. 

 

Enterovirus 70 is known to cause acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, presenting with eye redness, pain, and subconjunctival hemorrhage. 

 

Coxsackie B virus is a frequent cause of myocarditis, which can present with symptoms of heart failure in infants and children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the specific associations between viruses and the diseases they cause: Coxsackie A virus with herpangina, Enterovirus 70 with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, and Coxsackie B virus with myocarditis.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p481, 2/e p500-501

choices.text: Detection of rabies virus antigen in saliva using an enzyme immunoassay
Isolation of the rabies virus from serum
Detection of rabies virus RNA in saliva using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a history of hydrophobia and aerophobia. He reports being bitten by a stray dog about a month ago. On examination, he appears anxious and has difficulty swallowing. His family reports episodes of agitation and confusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis of rabies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of rabies virus RNA in saliva using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)

 

Option C:

 

The most accurate method to confirm rabies in a living patient is to detect rabies virus RNA in saliva using RT-PCR. This method is highly sensitive and specific and can provide results quickly, which is crucial for a disease like rabies that requires immediate intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Detection of rabies virus antigen in saliva using an enzyme immunoassay can be used, but it is less sensitive than RT-PCR.

 

Option B. Isolation of the rabies virus from serum is not commonly done due to the low concentration of the virus in the blood and the invasive nature of the procedure.

 

Option D. A CT scan of the brain is not specific for rabies and cannot confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies in a living patient - RT-PCR is the diagnostic test of choice due to its high sensitivity and specificity, especially in patients who present with hydrophobia and aerophobia after a dog bite. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p499, 2/e p520

choices.text: Noncritical items also included in classification
Semicritical items contact with mucous membrane
Semicritical items need low disinfectant
Cardiac catheter, e.g., of critical items

questions.text: During a hospital infection control meeting, a debate arises about the Spaulding classification system for disinfection and sterilization. One of the statements made about the classification is incorrect. Which of the following statements about the Spaulding classification is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Semicritical items need low disinfectant

 

Option C:
 

The false statement is that semicritical items need low-level disinfectants. Semicritical items, which contact mucous membranes or non-intact skin, require high-level disinfection, not just low-level disinfection.

 

Semicritical items are those that come in contact with mucous membranes or minor skin breaches and they need high level disinfectant for sterilization.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. True - Noncritical items are included in the Spaulding classification and typically require less stringent disinfection.
 

Option B. True - Semicritical items do contact with mucous membranes.
 

Option D.- Cardiac catheters are considered critical items as they enter sterile areas of the body and require sterilization.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p42, 2/e p44, Ananthanarayan 10/e p35

choices.text: Cetrimide + Butyl alcohol
Cetrimide + Chlorhexidine + Butyl alcohol

questions.text: A nurse is preparing a solution for cleaning wounds and needs to know the active components of Savlon, a commonly used antiseptic. Which of the following constitutes the active ingredients in Savlon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cetrimide + Chlorhexidine

 

Option A:


Savlon contains two active ingredients: cetrimide and chlorhexidine. Cetrimide is a quaternary ammonium compound with detergent and antiseptic properties, while chlorhexidine is a broad-spectrum biocide effective against a range of bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Cetrimide + Butyl alcohol - This combination is not the active ingredient in Savlon.
 

Option C. Cetrimide + Chlorhexidine + Butyl alcohol - Butyl alcohol is not a component of Savlon.
 

Option D. Cetrimide + Cetavlon - Cetavlon is not an active ingredient in Savlon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Savlon, a widely used antiseptic, primarily contains two active ingredients: cetrimide and chlorhexidine. Cetrimide, a quaternary ammonium compound, offers detergent and antiseptic properties. Chlorhexidine, on the other hand, is a broad-spectrum biocide effective against various bacteria, viruses, and fungi. This combination makes Savlon effective for cleansing and disinfection purposes.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p39

questions.text: In a training session for new hospital staff, the topic of evaluating the efficacy of disinfectants is being discussed. The instructor mentions a specific coefficient that is used as a standard to measure the effectiveness of a disinfectant. What does the phenol coefficient - (Rideal Walker) test indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Efficacy of a disinfectant

 

Option A:
 

Testing efficacy of disinfectants by Phenol coefficient (Rideal Walker) test - Phenol coefficient is determined by the dilution of the disinfectant in question which sterilizes the suspension of S. typhi in a given time divided by the dilution of phenol which sterilizes the suspension in the same time.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Dilution of a disinfectant - The phenol coefficient does not indicate the dilution of a disinfectant.
 

Option C. Quantity of a disinfectant - It does not represent the quantity of the disinfectant used.
 

Option D. Purity of a disinfectant - The phenol coefficient does not measure the purity of a disinfectant.

 

Educational Objectives: 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p40, 2/e p41, Ananthanarayan 10/e p35.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, bedridden in the ICU with a urinary catheter, develops a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Considering the common pathogens and resistance patterns in India, which of the following is the most appropriate choice of antibiotic for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta lactams/beta lactamase inhibitors

 

Option B:

 

In bedridden patients in ICU, cause of catheter associated -UTI and VAP are usually the multidrug resistant gram negative bacilli. Therefore, empirically Beta lactams/beta lactamase inhibitors such as Piperacillin-tazobactam or Cefoperazone-sulbactam can be started which can be tailored later based on culture/sensitivity report.

In ICU settings for patients with Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infections (CAUTI) and Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP), beta-lactams combined with beta-lactamase inhibitors are often the preferred choice. This combination effectively addresses a wide range of bacteria, and the addition of beta-lactamase inhibitors helps counteract resistance in certain bacterial strains. This is particularly relevant in the context of the common pathogens and resistance patterns observed in India.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Amoxicillin - Not broad enough for the typical pathogens associated with CAUTI and VAP, especially in an ICU setting.

 

Option C. Third-generation cephalosporin - While useful, they may not cover all the potential pathogens, especially those producing beta-lactamase.
 

Option D. Second-generation cephalosporin - Generally less effective than third-generation cephalosporins and beta lactams/beta lactamase inhibitors for these infections.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Beta lactams/beta lactamase inhibitors are often the choice in ICU settings for patients with CAUTI and VAP, especially when considering the common pathogens and resistance patterns in India. These antibiotics are effective against a wide range of bacteria and the addition of beta-lactamase inhibitors helps overcome resistance in certain bacteria.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology 2/e p644,665
